Our experience with incineration in Baltimore in the United States raises some additional issues. Incinerator operators require a consistent supply of material to burn and work to lock governments into contracts that specify a certain tonnage of waste. If a government delivers less than the agreed upon amount they are vulnerable to millions of dollars in penalties. So, incentives are set up to do the opposite of what common sense suggests: compost, re-use, reduce and recycle to the greatest extent we can and re-design for products with minimal or no waste. I've never encountered a human being who thinks it's a bad idea to produce less waste...we have encountered relationships between incinerator companies and governments who create structural relationships hidden in the background that encourage and even depend upon the creation of more and more waste. On top of that, some governments have classified trash incinerators as a source of renewable energy alongside wind and solar making them eligible for millions in public subsidies.

..p.s. -pyrolisis IS in fact, the very process that Sweden /or whomever employs in order to [in effect] extract energy from garbage. what happens is, biomass (ie. garbage) under pyrolisis, gives you syngas. Take that syngas into a combustion chamber where oxygen (ambient air) is introduced & an ignition source is present & boom, you get full combustion. This in-turn, produces a good amount of continuous heat. Now in a closed-loop system, a portion of this heat can be diverted off to be utilized @ start of this whole process in contributing either partly (along w/ supplemental fuel) or fully in faciliting pyrolisis. Otherise, 100% of the heat will go towards creating the necessary steam pressure that will spin the turbines which, ya' guessed it..generate the electricity. the end.

Just a small note of criticism. If waste products i.e paper and waste foods were burned for energy, by its carbon cycle, it had absorbed as much carbon from the atmosphere by photosynthesis as it releases by burning, hence is carbon neutral, and absorbs it quickly (short lifespan of growing, e.g couple years). Oil on the other hand, which had absorbed carbon for millions of years from the atmosphere, is not so carbon neutral, as it is a slow process, the carbon that it collected in millions of years currently being released within a couple centuries of use. Not to mention the slow running out of natural gas...

As you said in the video, about the prices of combusting waste for energy, by actual fact, it is just about the same price per megawatt hour electricity to oil, due to the high demand, low supply of oil, which will only push the prices up even more as time progresses.

I think people should be use to the idea that land filling plastics is better than burning them. While funny enough landfilling organic waste is usually worse than burning. Thats why these two wastes should be separated. Further the worst types of plastic waste tend to be plastic thats recyclable material but can't be recycled because its covered in food. This leaves a major point of improvement in waste management. We either come up with a vastly cheaper way of managing food contaminated plastic or we avoid packaging food in plastic. Like by using glass bottles or minimizing plastic use by using liners that can be thrown away while the bulk structural plastic is recycled.

Nice video, nice to see you talking about our huge Waste problem and also Climate Crisis, BUT I wouldn't be so optimistic about recycling.

Plastic can't be recycled more than a couple of times and not all platic products can be recycled. Developed countries ship their waste to developing countries in Asia and Africa for them to "recycle it" and then a lot of it ends up in the oceans.

The only solution to this dilemma in my opinion is adopting the Zero Waste approach, i.e., just producing less wasteful products (such as plastic straws, bags, cutlery) and encouraging the use of reusable alternatives. NOT organic disposable alternatives, such as paper straws or bamboo cutlery. Just no disposable waste.

I feel like way more needs to be said about pyrolysis.

It's my understanding that pyrolysis works with any carbon-rich wastes. Wood, paper, plastics, yard waste, food waste, etc. Notable exceptions are metals and toxic elements most often found in batteries and electronics. After being combusted in an 800 C, oxygen depleted oven the solid residue is almost entirely carbon, known to us as charcoal. Follow up with high-pressure steam and you get activated charcoal. Add activated charcoal to sewage wastes and you're left with a super-charged soil additive.

What I worry about and I've found no information on is whether there are any undesirable by-products. Are there any dangerous gases produced from pyrolysis of some plastics or chemicals in the paper or plastics? Are there circumstances that the charcoal could become a toxic waste?

The only sliver of truth in that Sweden story is that Sweden does collect most of its plastic «for recycling». Sweden and Denmark have high electricity prices, so they burn the lowest-quality plastic for energy and transport the higher quality plastic to Germany. Norway have near endless hydropower so they send all of it to Germany. Plastic can only be efficiently recycled into severely inferior quality plastic, which means Germany can only recycle a fraction of what they receive from all over Europe into new products. About half of the rest is burned for energy in Germany, while the remainder is shipped in containers to Asia. Nobody really knows what happens to it there, most likely it is dumped in landfills since burning it requires more energy than it yields at this point. This is your nightmare scenario of endless landfills with starving children digging through the trash for anything usable. «Recycling» in Sweden, and indeed most of the western world, is a complete joke.

As a European, I'm constantly baffled by how this works in supposedly developed countries like the US. Here in Europe, landfills are basically illegal. But how you put it with burning organic waste and not plastic is not at all how it usually works. Paper for example is recyclable to around 90%, that isn't burned. And other organic waste just decomposes. The key ist that we sperate everything by type, so things aren't just thrown into an incinerator together. Plastic on the other hand is only about 50% recyclable, so the rest is burned for energy since it's actually a really good energy source, similar to the oil it's made of. Of course though, just getting rid of non-recyclable plastic would be better.

The problems with landfills are not as great as people make them out to be.

Properly built and maintained landfills shred the garbage and bury it in a pit that collects all liquid runoff. Many will also collect the gaseous byproducts that would otherwise seep through the dirt and into the air.

Both the liquid runoff and gaseous emissions can be run through an incinerator and treated to an acceptable state before being released or stored.
